content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and effective

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash. Well-defined and clear.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Lovely coding challenge, nice difficulty for a clash of code and it is fun to solve the problem :)

Goal
* Please change "numbers" to "integers".

* Please either delete the example (because one example has been shown in Example section), or add some explanation to it.

Input
* Please change "numbers" to "integers".

Constraints
* Please change "[[n]]" to "length of [[n]]". If you mean elements in [[n]], then some cases violate the first constraint.

* Some cases violate the second constraint. Please fix it.

Thanks.
I've done everything you suggested. Thanks. I think the constraints should be fine now.

Constraints
* The second constraint is still violated:
  • The list in Test 2 contains 128.
  • The list in Validator 4 contains -100.

Cases
* Please change Validator 3 so that [[k]] > number of integers in [[n]], similar to Test 3.

* Please split the 4th pair of cases into 2 pairs:
  • First pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] < number of integers in [[n]]
  
  • Second pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] > number of integers in [[n]]

* Please add a pair of cases where [[k]] = number of integers in [[n]].

* Please add a pair of cases where [[k]] is negative and -[[k]] = number of integers in [[n]].

Thanks.
updated. surely nothing is wrong now :)

Thank you, but I don't see these points being followed up yet:

* Please split the 4th pair of cases into 2 pairs:
  • First pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] < number of integers in [[n]]
  
  • Second pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] > number of integers in [[n]]

* Please add a pair of cases where [[k]] is negative and -[[k]] = number of integers in [[n]].

Thanks.

tbh idk what u mean by:
* Please split the 4th pair of cases into 2 pairs:
  • First pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] < number of integers in [[n]]
 
  • Second pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] > number of integers in [[n]]

i think i have met these cases because for example i have used 70 numbers in validator 4 and my k value is -49. this meets ur first point about k being less than 0 and the absolute value of k which is 49 being less than the number of integers in n.

for the second pair, the validator for 4 has 87 numbers and the value for k is -93. this meets ur second point about k being less than 0 but the absolute value which is 93 is more than number of integers in n.
One pair of cases = Test + Validator.

What you described is one pair of two cases (70/-49 is one case, 87/-93 is one case), not two pairs of four cases. As I mentioned, I'd like to see the initial pair be split into two pairs.

Each pair of cases would be similar, i.e. the test is similar to the validator in each pair.
oh right that makes more sense. thanks

So, to recap:

* Test 4 and Validator 4: Please split the two cases into two pairs of four cases:

  • First pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] < number of integers in [[n]]
  
  • Second pair: [[k]] < 0 and absolute value of [[k]] > number of integers in [[n]]

* Please add a pair of cases where [[k]] is negative and -[[k]] = number of integers in [[n]].

After the revisions, there should be 7 pairs of cases in total. If you don't mind there being more cases, 3 additional pairs may be added (but this is up to you):

* [[k]] = 0

* 0 < [[k]] = multiple of number of integers in [[n]]

* 0 > [[k]] = multiple of number of integers in [[n]]

Thanks.

all done. also, i think you missed this but i had already added a pair of cases where [[k]] is negative and -[[k]] = number of integers in [[n]].
this was test 7

Thank you. Sorry I copied the wrong part of my earlier message. The missing pair should be:

* Please add a pair of cases where [[k]] = number of integers in [[n]].
